title: 103_hr4928
content: The "IDEA Improvement Act of 1994" aims to amend the Individualized Education Program to enhance the achievement of annual goals under the program. Amendments to the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act include adding statements on present levels of educational performance and annual goals for children in the general educational program. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act is amended to include a description of how services have been modified if previous annual goals were not achieved. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act is amended to require revisions to the individualized education program for children who did not meet annual goals in the previous school year. Increasing parental participation and improving information about the special education program. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act is being amended to increase parental participation in meetings and improve communication by providing clear explanations of relevant terminology. Additionally, a new subsection requires the Secretary to produce a publication describing procedural safeguards within six months of enactment. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act is being amended to enhance parental participation and communication by providing clear explanations of procedural safeguards available to children with disabilities and their parents or guardians. This publication will include steps for accessing safeguards, procedures for eligibility, evaluation, and educational placement, as well as the responsibilities of States and local educational agencies. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act is being amended to enhance parental participation and communication by providing clear explanations of procedural safeguards available to children with disabilities and their parents or guardians, including electronic form submission to Federal and State agencies and the general public. Establishment of mediation procedures for special education and early intervention services for infants and toddlers with disabilities. Mediation procedures for resolving disputes related to providing free appropriate public education to children with disabilities are required under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act mandates mediation procedures for resolving disputes regarding the provision of free appropriate public education to children with disabilities. These procedures must allow parties to resolve disputes through mediation and meet specific requirements. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act mandates mediation procedures for resolving disputes related to special education services. The procedures ensure voluntary participation, access to due process hearings, a list of experienced mediators, state-funded mediation costs, and timely sessions at convenient locations. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act mandates mediation procedures for resolving disputes related to special education services. The agreement reached in the mediation process must be in writing and discussions are confidential. Amendments to the Act include requirements for regional resource centers. Amendments to the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act include providing information and training on informal dispute resolution techniques, including mediation. Parent training programs must now include understanding the use of mediation for resolving disputes related to special education services. Amendments to the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act now require states to include procedures for resolving disputes through mediation in early intervention services for infants and toddlers with disabilities. Amendments to the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act now mandate procedures for resolving disputes through mediation in early intervention services for infants and toddlers with disabilities, as outlined in Section 680 of the Act. SEC. 5. COORDINATION OF SERVICES UNDER THE SPECIAL EDUCATION PROGRAM. Interagency agreements are required for State education agencies and other relevant agencies under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. The effective date for this amendment is October 1, 1996. Additionally, coordination with Even Start, Head Start, and related programs is emphasized in the Act. The amendment requires coordination of programs to support parents of children with disabilities, including Even Start, Head Start, and other family literacy services. The term 'family literacy services' is defined in the Head Start Act as per an amendment to the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. SEC. 6 amends the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act to require a good faith attempt to resolve controversies before filing a complaint for attorney's fees reimbursement.
